docs.lead_paragraph: A fter his agent saw a screening of Bill Forsyth's latest film, the man stood up and said, ''Thank God. It's not a comedy.'' Mr. Forsyth agreed. ''It's a very sad film,'' he said, laughing heartily. This is quite a departure for the shy, 36-year old Scot who wrote and directed ''Gregory's Girl'' and ''Local Hero,'' and whose first ''wee film,'' ''That Sinking Feeling,'' opens at the Lincoln Plaza on Wednesday. He recently finished shooting his fourth and latest movie, ''Comfort and Joy,'' scheduled to arrive in New York late next fall. Why the agent and the filmmaker should have been thankful that the latest Forsyth effort has its sad side is a bit of a mystery. Because Bill Forsyth, all by himself, has put Scotland on the map of the world for his funny movies. ''Gregory's Girl'' won the British Academy Award for best original screenplay, beating out the British-made ''Chariots of Fire,'' which had won an American Oscar. Both ''Gregory's Girl'' - which critics called ''irresistible,'' among other things - and ''Local Hero'' have piled up praises and millions of dollars at box offices across the United States. They proved equally popular in Britain.

docs.lead_paragraph: Guatemalan opposition leaders are calling for the resignation of Interior Minister Gustavo Adolfo Lopez Sandoval, saying he has been unable to halt a recent surge in political violence. A communique issued on Thursday by the Guatemalan Christian Democratic Party said ''it is evident that the Interior Minister has shown irresponsibility and negligence in the face of the growing wave of violence that has hit the country.''

docs.lead_paragraph: A state district court in Austin, Tex., issued a temporary restraining order yesterday barring the Coastal Corporation from going ahead with its unwelcome takeover bid for the Houston Natural Gas Corporation. The surprise order was obtained by Jim Mattox, Attorney General of Texas. Houston Gas said it understood that Mr. Mattox would seek a permanent injunction. A hearing was set for Feb. 16 before Judge Harley Clark in Travis County District Court in Austin.

docs.lead_paragraph: Will a free sample vial of toilet water entice you to buy a bottle? Will a free packet of hair conditioner turn you into a customer? Manufacturers are betting they will. Since 1982, for example, Helene Curtis has spent over $10 million for free samples of its Finesse shampoo and conditioner. By mail, the packets reached the homes and presumably the heads of 82 million people. This program, plus an $18 million advertising effort in 1983 alone, helped to put Finesse in first place in the hair-conditioner market, with a 13.9 percent share, according to Diana Temple, a vice president at Salomon Brothers, the investment banking firm in New York. She was using information from Towne-Oller & Associates, which supplies monthly figures on 13,400 health and beauty products sold in food stores around the country. The shampoo already has attained a 4.5 percent share of its market, according to Towne-Oller, since its introduction last April.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Coastal Corporation, locked in an ever more intense takeover battle with the Houston Natural Gas Corporation, yesterday rejected as ''clearly inadequate'' a Houston Gas offer to buy Coastal for $50 a share, or $1.1 billion in cash. In an immediate reply, Houston Gas said Coastal's rejection ''does not affect our desire to proceed on a negotiated basis'' - an indication that it was prepared to raise its offer. Traders said Oscar S. Wyatt, chairman of Coastal, had personally assured several Wall Street executives by phone as early as Tuesday that he wanted to take over Houston Gas, that his bankers were supporting him and that he was not trying to provoke the company into taking over Coastal. In a telephone interview last night, Mr. Wyatt said in reference to persisent rumors that Houston Natural Gas had a suitor in the wings: ''So far they haven't unearthed a white knight or they wouldn't be struggling with me so much.''

docs.lead_paragraph: One of six Salvadorans accused by a former United States Ambassador of directing death squads in El Salvador says he will fly here this week to dispute the charge. The Salvadoran, Arturo Muyshondt, a banker whose family has holdings in cotton and dairy cattle in El Salvador, called the accusations totally false. In sworn testimony before the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Latin America today, former Ambassador Robert E. White said a source close to the exiles outlined their activities to the United States Embassy in San Salvador in January 1981. That information was sent to Washington. He said the six were all wealthy Salvadoran exiles based in Miami. Mr. White, now a professor at Simmons College in Boston, made public the text of his prepared testimony last week.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation said last night that it was prepared to offer $50 a share, or $1.1 billion in cash, for the Coastal Corporation if Coastal withdrew its offer to seek a controlling interest in Houston Natural Gas. Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., chairman of Coastal, said last night that that would not deter Coastal's bid. Coastal, which owns 5 percent of Houston Natural Gas, has offered $68 a share for 18.75 million shares more, which would give it a controlling interest of 50.7 percent. It also offered $60 a share in unidentified securities for the balance. But without details, Wall Street analysts tentatively valued the securities at about $55 a share.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reagan Asks For More Aid To El Salvador President Reagan agreed last week to make aid to El Salvador conditional on progress in human rights so long as the White House, not Congress, made the judgment calls. The President, acting on recommendations of his commission on Central America, said he would submit to Congress this week proposals to increase military aid to El Salvador by $312 million over the next two years as part of the commission's recommendation for $8 billion in total aid to the region over the next five years. Congress has already voted nearly $65 million in military help to El Salvador for fiscal year 1984 as part of a total economic and military aid package of some $570 million for Central America. Backing pro-American governments in the region ''won't be easy and won't be cheap,'' Mr. Reagan warned.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, since 1924 the financial mainstay of the band that has given free outdoor concerts in New York City parks, has ended its sponsorship of the band and the summer series because of other philanthropic commitments. However, Ainslee Cox, conductor for 17 years of the 54-piece ensemble, now known as the Guggenheim Concert Band, said the band would continue to give concerts if it found new financing. ''We have no funds at the moment,'' Mr. Cox said, ''but we never have funds this early in the year and we want to raise $300,000 before the still-scheduled opening of the series in mid-June at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center.''
